title: An Integrated Socio-Tehnical Crowdsourcing Platform for Accelerating Returns in eScience

author: Gianluca Demartini, L3S Research Center, Leibniz University of Hannover

This talk is about science.
In the past 100 years ago, scientific results were the outcome of gifted individuals of individual scientists putting a lot of efforts to.
Progress in science and find the new scientific results.
Today we see a shift which we see a change in how science is made.
And today we see science is more collaborative effort of many scientists working together in order to push science forward.
One example of such collaborations is the opera experiment.
As you may know, in this experiment they conclude that neutrinos can travel faster than the speed of light.
How did they reach such conclusion?
In at CERN in Geneva, a group of scientists and engineering build a huge machine to fire neutrinos from one side to the other.
And in the Grand Sasso lab in Italy they build a machine to catch to observe such neutrinos and measure how fast they are.
So this experiment involved hundreds of physicists on both sides, and this is a good example of how science today is a collaborative effort of people.
So today we are at the point in which a single scientist, an individual person, has not more anymore.
The ability to completely understand and observe all the information going on in such big experiments.

We need not only computer scientist but we need psychologists and humanist in order to really understand what users do on the web and what's the behavior of user is.
So our claim in this paper is in the is that in the future the new discovery.

Such social technical system.

Overall, the entire scientific community.
Such system will enable cross pollination, which means that all the scientific artifacts have to be combinable and interoperable, and we will need and higher order logic to do this.

So in the future, science will be the result of collective intelligence, which means we will not only have a group large group of scientists working together and collaborating, but we will also have a machine.
That will not just help the scientist to do science, but will work together with the scientist in order to foster science forward.
So what do we need to reach this point in the future?
We will definitely need highly expressive, machine readable formats.
We will need ontologies of quality we don't see today.

And this is needed because we will need basically to dump the knowledge in the science scientist mind into machine readable format so that this huge system is able to process and make a scientific process itself.
The machine will need to understand concepts, scientific assumptions, natural phenomenons and the abstraction that today scientists are making.
We need to create a mental map and dump it into machine readable formats for this system.
So that the machine can understand what is the scientific method going on in the scientific community.
This will create a gigantic crowdsourcing conceptualization machine.

The system will also be very useful to share scientific artifacts when a scientific result is reached.
An experimental observation is done.
This information has to be spread into the entire scientific community.
And this system as the time goes on, we'll overtime watching the what the scientists do an what, how the scientific process is going on we we will learn to make science itself.

It will help discriminate between contradicting experimental results.
If two experiments reach different conclusions which are contradicting, the system will be able to discriminate and explain why this happens.
Moreover, the system will be able to to reason and reason over experimental results and even propose a new experiment.
New experiments to perform.
So it will reason and infer new data and propose new experiments.
So the web in the future will be a collective intelligence engine.
Information systems will not be as we see them today as instruments to make science, but they will make science themselves.
They will be a catalyst for the scientific progress.

The systems will reason and combine scientific artifacts at a very large scale so they will take scientific results from different communities and see and try to understand how it's possible to combine and to run new experiments to push science forward.
